data.title: Derek Jeter's No. 2 retired: See all New York Yankees retired numbers
data.meta_description: Derek Jeter is the 22nd player to have his number retired by the New York Yankees.
data.text:
Photo: AP

New York Yankees retire Derek Jeter's No. 2

The New York Yankees will retire legendary shortstop Derek Jeter's No. 2 on Sunday in a pregame ceremony prior to a 7:30 p.m. game against the Houston Astros.

Jeter, a 14-time All-Star, is considered to be one of the most popular players in New York Yankees history. He retired following the 2014 season. The future Hall of Famer collected 3,465 hits, sixth most in baseball history, and won five World Series titles with the Yankees over his 20-season career.

The Yankees will also give him a plaque in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium.

Jeter will become the 22nd player to have his number retired by the Yankees. Here is a look at the Yankees legends Jeter will join in that club.

Photo: AP

No.1 Billy Martin

Billy Martin's No. 1 was retired by the Yankees in 1986.

Martin played an integral part in four World Series in the 1950's as a player and added another ring managing the Yankees in 1977. His .333 lifetime World Series batting average is fourth with at least 75 at-bats on the all-time list.

Martin famously was fired and re-hired by former Yankees owner George Steinbrenner five times.

Photo: AP

No.3 Babe Ruth

"Heroes get remembered, but legends never die"

That's what a fictional Babe Ruth told young Benny Rodriguez in the movie 'The Sandlot.'

Ruth is baseball's greatest legend and one of its most colorful figures.

'The Sultan of Swat' was sold to the Yankees for $120,000 by Red Sox owner Harry Frazee in 1920 and his 54 home runs that year were more than any other American-League team.

Ruth hit 714 career home runs,, hitting 60 in 1927. He led the Yankees to seven World Series appearances, winning four titles.

Ruth is a member of the inaugural class of Baseball Hall of Fame inductees in 1936.

His No. 3 was retired by the Yankees in 1948.

AP

No. 4 Lou Gehrig

Lou Gehrig played in 2,130 consecutive games for the Yankees between 1925 and 1939.

Gehrig drove in at least 100 runs for 13 straight seasons (1926-38) and established an American-League record with 184 RBI in 1931.

Gehrig compiled a .340 lifetime batting average and hit 493 home runs in a career shortened by terminal illness.

He was honored at Yankee Stadium on July 4, 1939 where he delivered the famous "luckiest man on the face of the earth" speech.

Gehrig was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1939. His number was retired by the Yankees that same year.

AP

No. 5 Joe DiMaggio

The "Yankee Clipper" is one of the best all-around baseball players in history.

DiMaggio compiled a .325 lifetime batting average from 1936 to 1951. DiMaggio, a three-time MVP, powered the Yankees to the first of four consecutive World Championships in his 1936 rookie season.

DiMaggio's 56-consecutive-game batting streak, set in 1941, still stands as a record today. He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1955.

The Yankees retired his No. 5 in 1952.

Photo: AP

No. 6 Joe Torre

Joe Torre managed the Yankees to 1,173 regular season wins between 1996 and 2007.

Torre won 10 division titles, six American League pennants and World Series championships in 1996, 1998, 1999, and 2000.

The Brooklyn native earned American League Manager of the Year honors in 1996 and 1998.

His No. 6 was retired by the Yankees in 2014. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2014.

Photo: AP

No. 7 Mickey Mantle

"The Mick" is one of the most popular players in Yankees history. He led the Yankees to 12 World Series appearances in 14 years that included seven World Championships.

He still owns records for most homers, RBI, runs, walks, and strikeouts in World Series play.

In 1956, Mantle had one of the greatest seasons ever at the plate. He hit 52 homers with 130 RBI and a .353 average to win baseball's Triple Crown.

Mantle spent his entire 18-year career with the Yankees, finishing with 536 home runs.

Mantle was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1974. The Yankees retired his No. 7 in 1969.

Photo: AP

No. 8 Bill Dickey

Bill Dickey is one of the greatest and most durable catchers in baseball history. He caught more than 100 games in 13 consecutive seasons (1929-41), an American-League record.

Dickey hit over .300 in 10 of his first 11 seasons while hitting 202 homers during his career. He handled Yankee pitching staffs on eight World Series teams, winning seven championships.

The Yankees retired his No. 8 in 1972.

Photo: AP

No. 8 Yogi Berra

Yogi Berra was a beloved Yankee for his play on the field and famous for expressions like "it ain't over till it's over" and "it's like deja vu all over again."

He won three Most Valuable Player awards and was selected to play in 15 successive All-Star games.

He played on 14 pennant winners and 10 world championship teams for the Yankees.

The former catcher also led the Yankees to the 1964 pennant as manager.

He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1972. The Yankees retired his number in 1972.

Photo: AP

No. 9 Roger Maris

In 1961, Maris hit 61 home runs, a Major-League record which stood until 1998 and is still the American-League mark.

The two-time American League MVP (1960-'61) is also considered as one of the best fielding right fielders in Yankee history.

The Yankees retired his number in 1984.

Photo: AP

No. 10 Phil Rizzuto

"Scooter" played for the Yankees for 13 seasons and went to the World Series in 10 of those seasons.

Rizzuto was a durable, outstanding shortstop, skilled bunter and enthusiastic baserunner who finished with .273 lifetime batting average.

In 1950 Rizzuto earned the A.L. MVP Award, batting .324 with 200 hits, 92 bases on balls, and 125 runs scored. He batted .320 in the 1951 World Series and was named MVP.

He also spent 40 years as a Yankee broadcaster (1957-96). Rizzuto was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1995. His number was retired in 1985.

AP

No. 15 Thurman Munson

Munson was a tremendous defensive catcher and the leader of the Yankee teams that won three AL pennants in a row (1976- 78) and two World Series titles.

Munson won the Gold Glove Award in three consecutive seasons (1973-75). From 1975-77, Thurman drove in more than 100 runs and hit better than .300.

He hit the first Yankee home run in the "new" Yankee Stadium.

Munson was tragically killed August 2, 1979 when the plane he was flying crashed while landing.

His number was retired in 1979.

Photo: AP

No. 16 Whitey Ford

"The Chairman of the Board" was the ace pitcher on the great Yankee teams of the 1950's and early 60's.

Ford, a lefty, was 236-106 in his career. The 1961 Cy Young Award winner still holds many World Series records, including 10 wins, 33 consecutive scoreless innings and 94 strikeouts.

He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1974. His number was retired by the Yankees in 1974.

Photo: AP

No. 20 Jorge Posada

Posada spent each of his 17 Major League seasons with the Yankees, batting .273 with 379 doubles, 275 homers, 1,065 RBI, a .374 OBP and .848 OPS in 1,829 games from 1995-2011.

Posada was also a five-time All-Star, five-time Silver Slugger winner and won five World Series with the Yankees.

He is one of just six catchers all time to have at least 11 seasons of 17-or-more home runs.

The Yankees retired his number in 2015.

Photo: AP

No. 23 Don Mattingly

"Donnie Baseball" was the 10th captain to be named by the Yankees in franchise history.

Considered one of the best first baseman of his era, Mattingly was a nine-time Gold Glove winner.

The 1985 American League MVP set records for most grand slams in a season (6), most home runs in seven consecutive games (9) and eight consecutive games (10).

His number was retired by the Yankees in 1997.

Photo: AP

No. 32 Elston Howard

Elston became the first black player in Yankees history when he made the club in the spring of 1955.

Howard is a two-time Gold Glove-winning catcher who won A.L. pennants with Yankee teams in nine of his first ten seasons.

The 1963 American League MVP, Howard was a respected clubhouse leader during his time in New York.

His number was retired in 1984.

AP

No. 37 Casey Stengel

Stengel spent 54 years in Major League Baseball and was one of the best ambassadors the sport ever had.

"The Old Professor" is remembered as one of the game's greatest managers.

He led the Yankees to 10 pennants and seven world titles in a 12-year span. He had a career record of 1,905â€“1,842.

Stengel was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1966. His number, also retired by the New York Mets, was put up in 1970.

AP

No. 42 Jackie Robinson

Jackie Robinson became the first African-American to play in Major League Baseball, breaking the color barrier in 1947.

His No. 42 was retired across MLB in 1997.

Robinson played for Brooklyn Dodgers from 1947-56. He was the recipient of the inaugural MLB Rookie of the Year Award in 1947. A six-time All-Star, Robinson won the NL MVP in 1949. Robinson played in six World Series during a 10-year career, helping the Dodgers win in 1955.

He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1962.

Photo: AP

No. 42 Mariano Rivera

Mariano Rivera is one of the most dominant closers in Major League Baseball history.

Rivera appeared in 1,115 regular season games, all with the Yankees, and compiled a major league-record 652 saves.

Rivera established postseason records with 96 games pitched, 42 saves, and a 0.70 ERA.

Rivera retired as the last major league player to wear uniform number 42.

The Yankees retired his number in 2013.

AP

No. 44 Reggie Jackson

"Mr. October" hit 563 career home runs, which is good for 14th all-time in MLB history.

In Game Six of the 1977 World Series, Jackson hit three home runs, all on the first pitch, as the Yankees beat the Dodgers to wrap up the club's first World Championship since 1962.

The 1973 American League MVP had a career slugging percentage of .490.

Jackson was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1993. The Yankees retired his number in 1993.

Kathy Willens

No. 46 Andy Pettitte

Pettitte pitched 15 seasons with the Yankees, winning 256 career games.

The left-hander is the franchise leader in strikeouts (2,448) and tied with Whitey Ford for the most starts. He trails only Ford (236 wins) and Red Ruffing (231 wins) in wins and innings pitched.

A three-time All-Star, Pettitte is the only pitcher drafted by the Yankees to win 200 games in the Majors.

Pettitte went 18-10 with a 3.76 ERA in 40 career postseason starts, winning five World Series titles (1996, '98-99, 2000, '09).

The Yankees retired his number in 2015.

AP

No. 49 Ron Guidry

Ron Guidry won 20 games in a season three times, in 1978 (25-3), 1983 (21-9) and 1985 (22-6).

"Louisiana Lightning" went 25-3 with a 1.74 earned run average in leading the Yankees to a dramatic comeback-from 14.0 games behind the Boston Red Sox-to capture their second straight World Championship in 1978. That season, he compiled a club-record 248 strikeouts and nine shutouts en route to a unanimous selection as the American League's Cy-Young-Award recipient.

On June 17, 1978 vs. the California Angels at Yankee Stadium, Guidry shattered the club's single-game record for strikeouts with 18.

A Yankees' co-captain with Willie Randolph from 1986 through his retirement in 1989, he remains in the Top 10 on the Yankees' all-time list in games pitched (368), innings pitched (2392.0), wins (170), winning percentage (.651), strikeouts (1778) and shutouts (26).

Guidry's number was retired by the Yankees in 2003.

Photo: AP

No. 51 Bernie Williams

Bernie Williams played his entire 16-year Major League career with the Yankees (1991-2006).

Williams had a career batting average of .297 with 449 doubles, 278 home runs and 1,257 RBI in 2,076 games.

A five-time AL All-Star (1997-2001), four-time Gold Glove winner (1997-2000) and Silver Slugger Award recipient (2002), Williams won the AL batting title in 1998 with a .339 average.

Williams was a four-time World Series champion (1996, '98, '99, 2000) and is the Yankees' all-time postseason leader in HR (22) and RBI (80) and ranks third in games played (121).

Williams' number was retired by the Yankees in 2015.
